title: The Chaos, the Madness, and the Highs I Shouldn’t Have Survived

content: “Geez, it’s a helluva time to be sober, huh?”

I said this jokingly to a friend of mine recently, a fellow addict living with HIV. We both snickered, but we know the truth. There’s no drug or booze that could make any situation, even the hell of what we all are living through in Orange Cheeto’s America, better.
I’m an addict several times over. My drug of choice is, “What do you have?”
I spent 12 years in active recovery for my alcoholism. I was in the community, part of the recovery chain of program people. I led meetings. I shared my experience. I baked cakes for  anniversaries.
They say addiction is cunning, baffling, and powerful. My inner addict certainly is that, because when I broke my sobriety by using crystal meth, no one was more surprised than I.

I’ve been very open about my alcoholism, but I haven’t shared much about my addiction to crystal meth. Society gives a gold star to the recovering alcoholic. There’s an understanding, a respect. Alcoholism is accepted as part of our general culture.

content: With a meth addict, there’s fear. There’s very little understanding about the drug or what happens to people who partake. There’s an unspoken tension when talking about meth addiction, an association with criminality, a griminess.
I realize addiction is a disease and not a disgrace. But I have a lot of regrets about crystal meth, especially about my last relapse. I’m deeply ashamed to talk about it.

About three years ago, I was in love with this guy. I wouldn’t have admitted it at the time, but yeah, I was a goner. I wasn’t getting what I wanted out of the relationship, so I did drugs at it. It was that simple. That sounds crazy to a normie, (“Why would you throw away 12 years of sobriety so easily?”) but an addict can certainly relate.
I spent the next 18 months, give or take, in and out of a meth fog, hanging out with other desperate users, barely remembering if I even asked their name.

content: Being on crystal meth is like being trapped inside a storm that never lets up.

The first rush hit like lightning: heart pounding, skin crawling. It felt like every nerve in my body was wide open. Nights turned into days without sleep, and my thoughts spun so fast I couldn’t tell if the scratching behind the walls was real or just in my head.

Every sound felt like a threat, whether footsteps outside, a knock at the door, or thinking there were cops looking for me around every corner.. I spent months hiding from apartment workers in my building who didn’t exist. Sex was the main activity – frantic, desperate, and fueled by a body that wouldn’t shut down and a mind too wired to rest.
I was around people all the time, yet I never felt so lonely.

My home smelled like burnt chemicals and looked like a junkie lived there: scattered pipes, sex toys, trash filling the small space. Well, a junkie did live there. Me. I felt dirty, but none of that mattered as long as I had another hit lined up.

content: Coming down was worse. Intense itching, jaw grinding, and depression so heavy I couldn’t crawl out of bed. Yet, I kept going back for more.

One day, in the midst of another methy day, I stood in my tiny apartment and saw the future. It was so clear to me, there wasn’t one. If I kept going, I was going to lose my apartment, get arrested, be put in a mental hospital, or die. Those are not glamorous choices.
I called my friend Jason. We’ve been friends forever, and there’s no one who knows or understands me more. I needed to come clean to someone that I’d been smoking crystal.
After my confession, Jason was silent. I knew he was worried for me, and glad that I’d decided to quit. Finally, he broke the quietude by sassily chiding, “Oh, sweetie, did you think you were young?”
We both cracked up. Sarcasm is our love language. That was my first genuine laugh in 18 months. It was the beginning of my recovery.

content: I threw away the crumbs left of my drug stash. A week later, I threw away all my paraphernalia and a week after that, I blocked everyone on my phone that had any connection to crystal.

I’ve been away from meth since February, 2024. (And if we’re still counting, I also haven’t had a drink since 2010.) Miraculously, I was able to somehow stay compliant with my HIV medication, staying undetectable the entire time I was using.

I lost a lot because of this relapse, including two people I cared about. One was the guy I was in love with, who’ll never speak to me again due to how I behaved while under the influence. I also think I may have done some real damage to my brain. I aged 5 years during that 18 months of drug disorder.

When I first stopped using, I went to a few recovery meetings. But I realized that this time around that it’s not for me. I’m not interested in sharing. I don’t want to relive the experiences. I don’t want to talk about it. I don’t want to hear others’ confessions.

content: I also have a really hard time these days with the concept of a Higher Power. People of faith have created more harm than good in this world. There’s more than one way to heal from addiction, and I’m choosing a different path.

Life isn’t easy. Especially not now, with threats to our very beings coming from everywhere. If you’re in an addictive situation, be it meth, or booze or coke or any other drug you can’t control, you’re not alone. There are people to help you, if you choose. Reach out to your doctor, local clinic, or HIV service organization. Or simply talk to a friend. They’ll be happy you reached out.
No matter what – whether you’re an addict in recovery, a drug user who doesn’t want to recover, or somewhere in between – you’re worthy.

content: You’re worthy of love, care, safety, and respect. I carry you in my heart. Please be safe. The world needs you in it.
Today, I’m not struggling with my addictions. I’m not the person I was in the fog, and hopefully I never will be again. That’s the gift recovery gives me: myself.
